title: Reinforcement – Practice and Derivatives
goals: Strengthen recall of Second Conjugation endings
Identify English derivatives from Latin roots

steps.speak: Salve! Let’s begin with both families together. Chant the –āre verbs: amō, amās, amat … now the –ēre verbs: videō, vidēs, videt …
Excellent! What sound marks the Second Conjugation?
Yes—the long ē sound. Now let’s see English friends: videō → video; moneō → monitor; teneō → tenure; habeō → habit; timeō → timid.
Say each Latin verb, then its English child word.
Compare: amō (I love) and videō (I see). Both end in –ō. Why?
Because both verbs are 1st person singular—good memory!
Drill endings: I = –eō, you = –ēs, he/she = –et, we = –ēmus, you all = –ētis, they = –ent.
Quick quiz: what ending tells us 'they'?
Yes—–ent. Now build: Puella videt aquam. Puer habet librum. Translate both.
Correct—'The girl sees the water.' 'The boy has the book.' Diligent work shows prudent seeing.
Faith phrase: Deus videt – God sees. Say it three times softly, wisely.
Tomorrow we’ll join –āre and –ēre verbs in real reading. Bene factum!
